Correct that the lower CRPS score is better. We've actually moved to a 'prompt_score_v2', which we'll get hooked up to the API shortly. Prompt_score_v2 will be equal to the CRPS score of that miner - the CRPS for the best miner, capped at the 90th percentile of CRPS scores. So now the lower the prompt score v2 the better as well. We then take the exponential moving average of those prompt scores, and then apply the softmax function to get the reward weights. We'll update the github accoridingly.

Expect some chaos in the scores today, while the validators switch over to the new system, and then the moving average will take some time to stabilise the scores

As a correction to my above response, we've already hooked up the new prompt score to the API. So yes, the prompt score you're seeing there of 0 is from the new version, and yes the best miner for a prompt will score 0 and all the other miners will have a positive prompt score.  Basically the prompt score now corresponds to a penalty for your miner compared to the best miner.

Here's a brief overview of the changes (we're adding them to the whitepaper and the github shortly):

- Keep the CRPS sum method the same

- Changed the prompt scoring method to be: Order all the miners by their CRPS sum, cap the highest (worst) possible score at the score of the 90th percentile miner, subtract the lowest CRPS sum (best score) for that prompt from all the miners scores. So the best miner has a score of 0 and the other miners have positive prompt scores. For miners that failed to submit predictions in the correct format, or in time, assign them the 90th percentile score

- Apply the exponential moving average in the same way we're doing currently to go from the prompt score to the smoothed score. Keep the half life at 2 days, and the cutoff at 4 days

- To get the reward, now apply the softmax function (in the same way that we're currently doing in the prompt scoring step) with a Beta of -0.003. The alpha parameter is no longer used

Scoring system still favours directional predictions

Yeah, on some occassions we're still seeing miners with directional predictions reaching near the top of the leaderboard.  We can increase the EMA window, and that will fix that. However, while we're still adding complexity to the competition (soon we want to introduce more assets), there's a concern that increasing the EMA too much starts to really penalise any slip ups in reliability (i.e. if you miss a prompt for whatever reason, that bad score would impact you for a long time period), plus it could put off new miners. Hence why we're keen to ramp up the EMA window slowly.

In the meantime, we can add an extra aggregation layer when picking the 'best' miners for powering the tools built on top of Synth data. I.e. choose the miners based on the sum of their rewards over the last 2 weeks, to ensure that directional predictions don't spoil the Synth forecasts. But long term we want to avoid having 2 separate definitions for 'best', and ensure that the 'best' miners are getting the highest rewards in any given instant, and are getting the highest rewards cumulatively

We've got a few options for fixing this:
Increase the EMA window
Decrease the value of beta (i.e. increase the steepness of the rewards curve)
Artificially increase the registration cost / wait for the registration cost to reach a higher equilibrium value

Also, when we move to phases 2 and 3 of the contest (increase the number of assets and time frames, and request correlated path predictions across multiple assets) the added complexity will favour more advanced models
We could also make beta adaptive so as to always achieve the same steepness of the reward function, irrespective of the current volatility in the market

If you increase reg cost now you will stuck with bunch of useless models, you should penalise directional predictions. Increasing beta will likely help too but I would be careful with that.

The Synth team has been making rapid progress over the last few weeks. Here's an update of where we're at, and what's coming next

The competition:
Last week's change to increase the EMA half life for our smoothed score has worked out very well. The top 10 places on our leaderboard are now all occupied by miners who are putting effort into producing advanced models, with variable volatility with the changing market regimes, and with daily and weekly volatility patterns. Crucially these top miners all appear to be holding their alpha token rewards and not selling a single token, so evidently they believe in the long term value of the project. The people who were profiting previously by spinning up loads of simple GBM miners have fallen down the leaderboard and have seen their rewards cut significantly. We're working on a review of the accuracy of Synth predictions over the last month, and the preliminary results are very impressive. Soon we'll be expanding to multiple assets (more news on that to come soon).

Tools:
Our advanced dashboard for miners is now complete: https://miners.synthdata.co/
Featuring a whole host of tools to track the performance of your miners vs the competition, and for tracking market movements and volatility, to help enable you to build even better models (we'll do another post that delves into the page in more depth)

We have a collection of insights pages that we're putting the finishing touches on, which we'll release to the public over the coming week. These use live predictions from the subnet to show off the versatility of the Synth data, including probabilities of liquidations, options prices and metrics for liquidity providers. These are proving integral in our discussions with protocols, with lots of promising B2B deals on the table

Alpha Token:
The Discord rules imply that we can't promote the alpha token on here, nor can we discuss price. But judging by the performance of token over the last day, it looks like the community are starting to realise the value of Synth and the power of the data we're producing. We are keen to start discussions here about how best to make use of the alpha token though, and how to ensure value for alpha stakers. One option, now that the token is transferrable, is to use it as 'skin in the game' where miners effectively bet on their own predictions with alpha token, and risk losing it if they don't reach a certain position in the leaderboard. Lots of details there still to be worked out, but it would help further incentivise competitors to concentrate their modelling resources into a single miner, instead of spinning up multiple miners to cover 'parameter space'

Exciting times

Phase 1 of the Synth Roadmap is now complete! Miners have risen to the challenge of predicting BTC paths for the next 24 hours, with many highly competitive models emerging, and the collective wisdom of our subnet smashing typical benchmarks. Thank you for your hard work so far, but now it's time to ratchet up the complexity, and embark on Phase 2

The first step of Phase 2 is for miners to expand their models to handling requests for predictions for additional assets. From Monday 19th May, validators will also be sending out requests 100 paths of Eth price predictions for the next 24hours, at 5min increments. The default code has been updated so that validators will alternate between sending out requests for BTC and ETH predictions, at 30min intervals.

To facilitate this change, the mechanics of the scoring have already been adapted, so that the CRPS values are calculated on the price change in basis points for each interval. This allows the prompt scores to have the same 'units' for all assets, and hence for the smoothed score to be calculated using an EMA over all prompts, irrespective of which asset the prompt corresponds to.

For miners, we'd recommend splitting your model based on the asset in the prompt here: synth/miner/simulations.py. And for getting the current price, if you are using the Pyth oracle, make sure to use the correct token symbol, as outlined here: synth/validator/price_data_provider.py

Let us know if you have any questions!

@here important notes for miners in preparation for the ETH prediction starting next Monday. 
**CRPS Calculation Update for BTC and ETH Prediction Prompts**
Prompt scores are calculated individually for each asset prediction—either BTC or ETH. When we report the overall smoothed score, we take a moving average of these individual prompt scores across all assets.

**How Prompt Scores are Calculated:**
Individual interval CRPS values are now computed by comparing the real price change in the interval as a fraction of the price at the start of the interval, measured in basis points (100th of a percentage point), against the distribution of the price changes across the paths predicted by the miner, also measured in basis points.
 For example, if BTC is priced at $100K at time T₀ and rises to $102K at T₀ + 5 minutes, the price change is +200 basis points. Each miner’s predicted distribution is then compared against this 200bps change to calculate the CRPS for that interval.
CRPS is calculated across multiple time intervals: 288 x 5 minutes, 48 x 30 minutes, and 8 x 3 hours.
A second component of the CRPS scoring is **applied only to the final path price **provided by miners. This compares the distribution of the absolute predictions of the final price, with the actual crypto price at that time. This final CRPS value is then divided by the real price and multiplied by 10,000, to also give it the units of basis points. These 344 interval scores and 1 absolute score are summed to give the 'CRPS Sum' for the miner for that prompt
Prompt Scores are obtained by capping very bad CRPS sums, or miners with missing predictions, to the 90th percentile CRPS Sum (i.e. top 10% worst value). and then subtracting the best CRPS Sum (lowest score). So a prompt score of 0 is the best possible outcome, and anything higher represents an increasingly worse score

**ETH Prediction Update:**
Starting Monday 19th at 2 PM UTC, validators will start sending ETH prediction prompts, followed by BTC prompts 30 minutes later. This alternating schedule will continue at the same hourly cadence.
Every hour, we compute a moving average of prompt scores, using all prompts across both assets from the last 7 days, with more recent data weighted more heavily. The final smoothed score will therefore eventually be an **equally weighted average of BTC and ETH (50/50) prompts** (until Tuesday 27th, there will still be more scored BTC prompts present than Eth prompts in the past 7 days lookback window, courtesy of the BTC only period up to the 19th)
Reward weights are still calculated using the Softmax of the smoothed score, using the same Beta value as is used currently

**Implications for Miners:**
Miners who only predict one asset will be significantly disadvantaged. Predictions for the other asset will be considered missing, and hence be assigned the 90th percentile score, greatly damaging their reward weights
Miners, please prepare accordingly.

In our Novelty Search talk we focussed on the things that Synth is doing well. For instance:
- Multiple researchers and groups are putting significant effort into producing good models, which our scoring mechanism is successfully filtering to the top of the leaderboard
- We're providing sufficient rewards to keep them improving their models, and to inspire them to expand their models to cover new assets
- The data being produced by the subnet is becoming increasingly predictive, and progressively encompasses more of the nuances of real asset price data
- We're managing to spread the word of the versatility of Synth data, and get it into the hands of real traders and liquidity providers, and partner with a variety of platforms to empower their users (plenty more to do on this front)

But I'd also like to discuss the issues still facing the subnet, and how we plan to tackle them. I have two main concerns around the miners and the scoring mechanism:
1. One person or group is submitting the same set of the paths across all their miners. This isn't ideal, as it limits the accuracy of any probabilities or options prices etc we can draw from the subnet, and it means our synthetic data is not 'infinitely generatable', as we've been promising. My suspicion is this person is using a 'bootstrapping' method of borrowing price changes directly from real historic paths. Technically it's a legitimate approach, but ideally they'd find a way to be able to use bootstrapping to generate a variety paths, instead of just 100, if they're set on using this method.

2. The other contestants are designing increasingly good models, however they've now embarked on spinning up many miners each. This is to be expected, and isn't necessarily bad on its own, as the miners with the best paths should still filter to the top of the subnet. However, it does encourage contestants to use slightly different models or different parameters on each miner, instead of focusing on creating a single best model or parameter set. Also, the game of registering and managing many miners takes their focus away from building models, and reduces the rewards for anyone not used to playing the 'many miners' game on Bittensor

Both of the problems can be steered in the right direction by increasing the steepness of our rewards curve (just by adjusting the value of our beta parameter). In case 1 it incentivises them to use different paths to have some variety in their submissions (there's an interesting proof of this using Jensen's inequality, I'll try and do a much more in-depth post around this, and game theoretic equilibriums of miner counts per contestant), and for both 1 and 2 it puts the focus more on building the best possible single miner to come top of the leaderboard. So as of 4pm UTC today, validators will change from using Beta = -0.0475 to -0.1 in the softmax function that converts smoothed scores to reward weights

However, this needs to be accompanied by an increase in our exponential moving average window, so contestants can't just aim to reach near the top of the leaderboard on rare occasions through luck (to collect the increased proportion of rewards for being near the top), and similarly so the overfitting to historic data in case 1 becomes increasingly punished

The introduction of Eth predictions has already dampened the impact of luck, but still we will accompany this change of Beta value with a change in the EMA half-life from 3.5 to 5 days and the window length from 7 days to 10 days. To give new miners a fair chance, we will also increase the immunity period from 3 days to 5 days

In summary, the rewards curve will be getting steeper, and the window over which we smooth performance will be getting longer. Miners, you don't need to make any changes, just continue building great models, with a focus on producing consistently accurate and realistic predictions
Will miners currently in immunity also have their immunity period extended?
Nope

I’d also recommend to think about additional metrics or penalties. BTC and ETH most of the time do nothing so it makes sense to build a model with very narrow ranges to get CRPS as low as possible, if the assets move significantly from time to time bad score is simply ignored in the smoothed score as the low volatility periods dominate. You can see that in miners predictions, current best miners predictions kurtosis is insignificant if any, they lack any volatility. This reduces significantly credibility of these predictions. I’d recommend to add some sort of penalty for missing the moves or significant deviations from mean CRPS, so when the market moves these miners should be punished heavily to discourage static models.

Regarding the concerns around the miner immunity period, here's some analysis of the historic proportion of miners that manage to survive for the full current EMA window of 10 days (plus 1 day for the initial scoring delay). Admittedly the EMA window was shorter historically, but for this analysis we've used 11 days throughout:
The said analysis from Sam ^^

Historically, in April and the first half of May, the survival rate was fairly consistent and in excess of 50% (even with the longer 11 day measure), but from mid-May, the survival rate changed to swinging between 0% and 100%, i.e. being dictated just by the rate of new arrivals pushing out miners that had just left the immunity period but had yet to become competitive with old miners. This is backed up by our analysis and that of @fea_aelxi2, which shows that miners coming out of immunity after 5 days had very few 'long-term' miners below them in the leaderboard.

As an interim solution, we'll increase the immunity period to 7 days. Our simulations show that a miner with the quality of the 100th place on the leaderboard should still be competitive with some long lasting miners 7 days after registration.

However we will need to be very cautious about the number of concurrent immune miners not becoming excessive. We'll increase the registration price elasticity if the per day registrations exceeds 20 for multiple days in a row. So don't be surprised if the registration cost does increase as a result of this increase in immunity period. However the current ~$120 reg cost does seem like a bargain when the 10th and 20th place miners are earning $400 and $50 per day respectively. Remember this contest is about focusing on building high quality consistent models, not about running large numbers of average miners. For all of you working on improving your models, keep up the hard work, and you will be heavily rewarded!

We've observed that one or more miner groups are currently returning identical prediction paths in response to prompts, with multiple UIDs submitting the same outputs.

To anyone doing that, you'd be able to increase your total aggregate rewards by adding some variation between your paths (due to there being a slightly higher likelihood of one your miners taking a top spot, and being heavily rewarded as a result). That being said, due to the steepness of the rewards function, the benefit of running progressively more miners powered by the same model, even with different paths, also has diminishing returns per miner. And due to the long EMA, trying to run different models with a range of unoptimized parameters across multiple miners is also not beneficial. It also doesn’t affect the other miners rewards much.

Therefore we strongly encourage all participants to focus on improving model performance —prioritizing quality over quantity by deploying your best model across a smaller number of miners. This is the most effective path to earning meaningful rewards.

messages.content:
Validators will start sending prompts for gold prices from next Wednesday (9th July) at 2pm UTC. 

The exact asset to model is XAU/USD as priced by the Pyth oracle: https://www.pyth.network/price-feeds/metal-xau-usd
As with BTC and ETH, each validator will send a prompt per hour, with parameters:
    asset="XAU"
    time_increment=300
    time_length=86400
    num_simulations=100

However, unlike the crypto markets, the gold market is closed at certain times. Specifically between 5pm-6pm New York time on weekdays, 5pm Friday to 6pm Sunday and some national holidays (closing times can be found here: https://www.pyth.network/price-feeds/metal-xau-usd). Therefore validators will not send prompts between 5pm Friday and 6pm Saturday, as those 24 hour prediction windows would contain no price updates.

Note there will be prediction windows that encompass some periods where the market is closed. For 'V1' of our scoring mechanism, validators will not score any of the intervals where there's no Pyth price update (market closed) for either the start or the end of the interval. Therefore, although we recommend miners predict price changes of $0 during the closed periods, it won't be too damaging to their score if they don't.

Admittedly this does mean the V1 of scoring will miss out on judging the market opening intervals, which typically have higher volatility. We will find a way to encompass those in scoring at a later date. For now, for simplicity for the miners and the validators they will be ignored

The per prompt scores will be combined with the BTC and ETH prompt scores in the usual way (exponential moving average), to give the smoothed score, which will be Softmax'd to give the miner rewards

Good luck to all the miners with their modelling. If you have any questions, feel free to ask them on here

messages.content:
If you miss any prompt, the prompt score will be the highest possible, as high as 90th percentile of all the prompt score. And your crps will be -1. The same thing happens when you submit in an incorrect format.
If you have the best prediction, the prompt score will be 0. And you will have the lowest crps value. The minimum is 0. This means what you predicted has no difference from realized price. The smoothed score is calculated based on the moving average of your prompt score. 
the more detailed relationship is outlined here on readme https://github.com/mode-network/synth-subnet?tab=readme-ov-file#readme
